Buy Tickets Discover the Excitement of Law Enforcement Get ready for a day packed with thrills, adventures, and fascinating stories about the world of law enforcement. Buy Tickets About the Museum Plan Your Visit Explore the Campus Discover the Museum Discover Uncover the fascinating history and tools of law enforcement, including the Irish Connection digital exhibit, historic artifacts, vehicles and firearms. Experience Step into the action with interactive activities for all ages. Explore forensics, gadgets, crime-solving challenges, and exciting hands-on exhibits! Learn Explore inspiring stories of bravery from the men, women, and dogs that have shaped the law enforcement profession throughout history. Honor Celebrate the dedication and legacy of those who protect and serve every day, honoring their sacrifices at the largest indoor memorial to fallen officers. About the Museum The American Police Hall of Fame Museum offers an exciting, immersive journey into the world of law enforcement on the edge of Florida’s Space Coast. Here, you will discover a wealth of exhibits showcasing the tools, techniques, and brave individuals who have shaped policing throughout history. From interactive displays and hands-on activities to real-life police vehicles and iconic gear, the museum brings the thrilling and vital work of law enforcement to life. Whether you’re exploring crime-solving innovations, honoring the fallen, or learning about the heroes who serve, there's something for everyone to discover and enjoy. Read More Must See Attractions The Irish Connection Explore the profound influence of Irish Americans in policing with our Irish Connection digital exhibit. Celebrate their traditions, bravery, and lasting impact on law enforcement across the United States through captivating stories and a powerful documentary.... Read More The Memorial The Memorial Rotunda serves as a space for reflection and remembrance for all who visit, honoring 11,500 fallen officers, with each name etched on its walls.... Read More Big Adventures for Little Heroes Ignite your child’s imagination with hands-on law enforcement fun! From climbing into police vehicles to exploring forensic investigations and prison cells, our interactive exhibits inspire curiosity and creativity, making every visit an unforgettable adventure.... The focus though,is the memorial wall which contains the names of officers who have passed away in the... Anonymous March 20, 2023 To honor our fallen policemen, this museum is wonderful. Very helpful staff and an awesome tribute to our under-appreciated men and women (and K-9’s) of law enforcement. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit.... Robert May 20, 2022 A modern museum with many interesting displays surrounding the very moving memorial to the over 11,000 officers that have lost their lives in service. The very friendly & professional staff are very helpful, including offering to take pictures of visitors... Tracy October 3, 2017 Brilliant memorial for all fallen law enforcement whether they are human or K9. Brings a tear to your eye. My brother-in-law is a state trooper and this brought home how everyday he puts his life on the line for his... Read all reviews Get Ready for a Day of Adventure! About The Hall Located in Springfield, Massachusetts, the Naismith Basketball Hall of Fame is an independent non-profit 501(c)(3) organization dedicated to promoting, preserving and celebrating the game of basketball at every level. The Hall of Fame has more than 475 inductees and 40,000 sq. ft. of basketball history. Nearly 200,000 people visit the Hall of Fame Museum each year to learn about the game, experience the interactive exhibits and test their skills on the Jerry Colangelo "Court of Dreams." Best known for its annual marquee Enshrinement Ceremony honoring the game’s elite, the Hall of Fame also operates over 150 high school and collegiate competitions annually throughout the country and abroad. Off Become a Member Corporate Support DONATE NOW Shop Tickets Menu BOARD OF DIRECTORS Home ABOUT US Board of Directors JANE FORBES CLARK, CHAIRMAN Jane Forbes Clark is Chairman of the Board of Directors of The National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum. A member of the Board since 1992 and Chairman since 2000, she provides substantial museum expertise, philanthropic insight and management skill in this leadership position. Clark is currently Chairman of Bassett Medical Center and a Director of the Bassett Healthcare Network. She also serves as President of Fenimore Farm & Country Village, The Clark Foundation, The Scriven Foundation and The Clara Welch Thanksgiving Home, as well as a Trustee of the Fenimore Art Museum. She was a Trustee, Past President and CEO of the United States Equestrian Federation. Her previous roles have also included Vice Chairman of The Jackie Robinson Empire State Freedom Medal Commission, Trustee of The Little League Foundation, and past Vice Chairman and Trustee of The United States Equestrian Team and past Director of The United States Olympic Committee. She also served eight years as an Executive Board Member of the Fédération Equestre Internationale and Chairman of its Group IV. A recipient of many awards and honors, Jane has been recognized by the Preservation League of New York State with its Pillar of New York award; The Garden Club of America with the Zone Historic Preservation Award; the Fire Department of the City of New York with their Humanitarian of the Year award; Harlem R.B.I.; the Baseball Assistance Team; and is a member of the Boys’ Club of New York All Sports Hall of Fame. The Clark family has been a devoted steward of the Baseball Hall of Fame since Stephen C. Clark founded the Museum in 1936. JOE TORRE, VICE-CHAIRMAN Joe Torre is the Vice-Chairman of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum's Board of Directors. Appointed to the Board in 2023 and elected as Vice-Chairman in 2024, Torre followed his 18-year MLB playing career – where he was named to nine All-Star Games and won the 1971 National League Most Valuable Player Award – with a 30-year managerial career that saw him lead his teams to 13 first-place finishes, six pennants and four World Series titles. After retiring as a manager, Torre joined MLB’s front office, where he served in several roles as one of baseball’s most trusted voices. He was elected to the Hall of Fame in 2014. KEVIN MOORE, TREASURER Elected director and treasurer in 1992, Kevin S. Moore is president of The Clark Estates, Inc., a financial and business management company. Prior to joining The Clark Estates, he was president, chief executive officer and director of Jet Capital Corporation. Moore serves as a director on the governing boards of several business organizations and many charitable organizations. Moore is chairman of the Board's Finance and Pension committees, and is a member of the Executive Committee. PAUL BEESTON Elected to the Board in 1998 and a member of its Executive Committee, Paul Beeston served as president and chief operating officer of Major League Baseball from July 1997 to March 2002. He reported directly to the commissioner and was responsible for all phases of Baseball's central offices. An accomplished Toronto Blue Jays executive, he has served in many capacities, most notably as president and chief executive officer for nine years. CRAIG BIGGIO Elected to the Board of Directors in 2021, Craig Biggio was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2015 following a 20-year career with the Houston Astros as a catcher, second baseman and center fielder. A seven-time All-Star and member of the 3,000-hit club, Biggio earned four Gold Glove Awards and five Silver Slugger Awards. Now a Special Assistant to the General Manager with the Astros, Biggio was named Major League Baseball’s Roberto Clemente Award winner in 2007 for his efforts in the community. BILL DEWITT A director since 1998, William O. DeWitt Jr is chairman of the board and general partner of the St. Louis Cardinals. He is also president of RD Investment Group, a Cincinnati-based investment firm. DeWitt, whose father was a career baseball executive and club owner with the St. Louis Browns, New York Yankees, Detroit Tigers, Cincinnati Reds and Chicago White Sox, has also been a minority owner of the Texas Rangers, Baltimore Orioles and the Reds. He serves on the boards of a number of privately held companies and has worked in a number of civic and charitable organizations. DeWitt is a member of the board's Nominating and Development committees. TOM GLAVINE Tom Glavine, elected to the Board of Directors in 2021, won 305 games with the Braves and Mets over a 22-year big league career that earned him Hall of Fame induction in 2014. Glavine won the National League Cy Young Award in both 1991 and 1998 and was named the 1995 World Series Most Valuable Player for leading the Braves to their first World Series title in Atlanta. A 10-time All-Star, Glavine served as a respected voice during Collective Bargaining Agreement negotiations as a player representative throughout his career. KEN GRIFFEY JR. Ken Griffey Jr. was named to the Board of Directors in 2021, five years after he was elected to the Hall of Fame with what was then the highest percentage ever recorded in the Baseball Writers’ Association of America election. During 22 season with the Mariners, Reds and White Sox, Griffey Jr. hit 630 home runs, was a 10-time Gold Glove Award winner in center field, earned 13 All-Star Games selections and won the 1997 American League Most Valuable Player Award. As a Senior Adviser to MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred, Griffey’s work focuses on youth development and improving diversity at the game’s amateur levels. KEN KENDRICK Appointed to the Board of Directors in 2020, Ken Kendrick has served as the Diamondbacks’ Managing General Partner since 2004. In that time, Kendrick has led the Diamondbacks’ efforts in hosting the All-Star Game at Chase Field in 2011, opening a state-of-the-art Spring Training facility in Salt River Fields at Talking Stick and becoming one of the largest philanthropic entities in the Phoenix area with charitable contributions topping $70 million since the organization’s inception. ROB MANFRED Robert D. Manfred Jr. was named to the Board of Directors in 2015. Manfred served as the Chief Operating Officer of Major League baseball from Sept. 30, 2013 until he took over as the Major League Baseball’s 10th Commissioner on Jan. 25, 2015. Manfred served as MLB’s Vice President for Labor Relations and Human Resources from 1998-2012, helping negotiate successful extensions of the Basic Agreement that have maintained labor peace in the game for more than two decades. ARTE MORENO Elected as a director in 2018, Arte Moreno has guided the Los Angeles Angels as team owner since 2003. Along with his wife, Carole, Moreno’s work through the Angels Baseball Foundation supports investments in education, health care, arts and sciences, and community-related youth programs throughout Southern California. Through the Moreno Family Foundation, Arte and Carole support nonprofits focusing on youth and education. Kim Ng Elected to the Board of Directors in 2024, Ng currently serves as Commissioner of the Athletes Unlimited Softball League. She grew up playing softball and went on to play for the University of Chicago. After earning her degree, Ng joined the White Sox as an intern in 1990, working her way up through the team’s baseball operations department. In 1998, Ng was named the assistant general manager of the Yankees, helping the team continue its late-1990s dynasty. In 2002, Ng joined the Dodgers, where she spent nine years as vice president and assistant general manager. She then joined the MLB front office for a nine-year stint before she was hired as the Marlins general manager on Nov. 13, 2020. JERRY REINSDORF Elected to the Board of Directors in 2008, Jerry Reinsdorf is chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chicago White Sox. Since heading the limited partnership that purchased the White Sox in January 1981, Reinsdorf has been involved in Major League Baseball initiatives at an industry-wide level, as a member of the Executive Council, a past chairman of baseball's Ownership Committee and as a former member of the Player Relations Committee. Reinsdorf also serves as chairman of the Chicago Bulls. CAL RIPKEN JR. Cal Ripken Jr., elected as a director in 2019, was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2007 following a distinguished 21-year career with the Baltimore Orioles. In 1995, Ripken broke Lou Gehrig’s Major League record for consecutive games played (2,130), and then went another three seasons before voluntarily ending the streak after playing his 2,632nd consecutive game on Sept. 20 1998. In his post-playing career, Ripken is using the platform that baseball has provided him to help grow the game he loves at the grassroots level. He owns Ripken Baseball and, along with his family, founded the Cal Ripken, Sr. Foundation. Ripken Baseball currently operates youth baseball complexes, while the foundation operates nationally and serves over one million youth each year through programs and the construction of multi-purpose youth fields that provide kids with safe places to play. Ripken is also a Sports Diplomacy Envoy for the U.S. State Department. HARVEY SCHILLER Elected a director in 2009, Dr. Harvey W. Schiller is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the GlobalOptions Group, Inc. Previously, he served as President of the International Baseball Federation, the global governing body for the sport of baseball; Chairman and C.E.O. of Yankees/Nets; President of Turner Sports, Inc.; Executive Director and Secretary General of the United States Olympic Committee and Commissioner of the Southeastern Conference. OZZIE SMITH Ozzie Smith, elected to the board in 2016, was inducted into the National Hall of Fame in 2002. Since being inducted, he has served the as Museum’s first Education Ambassador, lending annual support to the Hall of Fame Classic as well as a fundraising event in his name. In a class by himself when it came to fielding at shortstop, Smith earning a record 13 Gold Glove Awards at the position, all in consecutive seasons (1980-1992). In addition to setting major league records for assists, double plays and total chances by a shortstop, Smith proved to be a valuable offensive weapon, amassing 2,460 hits and 580 stolen bases in his 19-year career, which included 15 All-Star selections. He was a key contributor to the St. Louis Cardinals World Series championship team in 1982. THOMAS TULL Elected to the Board in 2013, Thomas Tull is the founder, Chairman, and CEO of Tulco. Tull previously served as founder, Chairman, and CEO of Legendary Entertainment, a leading media company with film, television, and digital and publishing divisions. In January 2016, the company was acquired by the Dalian Wanda Group, Ltd. Tull also chairs Tull Investment Group which provides capital for early to mid-stage companies. During his career, Tull has produced and executive produced more than 40 films that together have realized grosses of more than $13 billion at the worldwide box office. Tull executive produced Straight Outta Compton and the world record-breaking Jurassic World. Other past credits include Godzilla, Pacific Rim , the critically acclaimed Jackie Robinson biopic 42 , the Dark Knight trilogy, 300 and 300: Rise of an Empire , The Town , Inception , Clash of the Titans , the Hangover franchise and Kong: Skull Island . Tull is part of the National Football League’s Pittsburgh Steelers ownership group, where he also holds a board seat. FAQ | American Police Hall of Fame Home About Us Memorial News & Events Shop Visit Us Award Program Donate Buy Ticket FAQ Got questions? We've got answers! Here you'll find all the information you need to make the most of your experience. If you don't find what you're looking for, feel free to contact us at policeinfo@APHF.org . Q: Where is the American Police Hall of Fame? A: We’re located at 6350 Horizon Drive, Titusville, Florida, just minutes from Kennedy Space Center and convenient to Orlando’s other attractions. Q: What are the museum’s opening hours? The museum is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM. Q: Is parking available? Yes, we offer free parking for all visitors. Along with disabled parking spots and space for buses. Q: Can I buy tickets at the door? We recommend buying your tickets online in advance to avoid disappointment, however if you are in the area visiting other attractions, you can purchase tickets on the door. Q: Are there discounts available? Yes! We offer discounted rates for veterans and active law enforcement officers. Q: Where does the money from ticket purchases go? The United States Law Enforcement Foundation is a nonprofit organization actively supporting law enforcement officers, their families and the wider community. The cost of tickets goes towards upkeep of the museum and memorial as well put into programs such as The Hope Initiative to fund scholarships, grants and anniversary gifts to families of fallen officers and those disabled in the line of duty. For the full list of programs visit uslef.org Q: Is the museum accessible for visitors with disabilities? Yes, the museum is fully wheelchair accessible, with designated parking and ramps for ease of access. Q: Are group tours available? Yes! We offer special rates and guided tours for school groups and other organizations. Q: How long should I plan for my visit? You can walk around the exhibits at your own pace. Most visitors spend about 2-3 hours exploring the exhibits and activities, but feel free to stay longer and enjoy everything we have to offer! Q: What is/isn’t included in admission? Your ticket gives you full access to the American Police Hall of Fame and Museum. For admission into the Shooting Range, you will need to book separately. Q: Are weapons permitted inside the museum? No weapons of any kind are permitted inside the American Police Hall of Fame and Museum including those belonging to off-duty law enforcement. Please leave items secured within your vehicle. About Us | American Police Hall of Fame Home About Us Memorial News & Events Shop Visit Us Award Program Donate Buy Ticket Discover America's First Law Enforcement Museum Buy Ticket Our Story A Legacy Begins Founded by retired Police Chief Gerald Arenberg, the American Police Hall of Fame becomes the nation's first law enforcement museum. Reaching the Community A foundation is established to support law enforcement and the community. Expanding Support Two programs are founded to aid families of fallen officers and provide assistance to those injured in the line of duty. Moving Forward The museum relocates to Miami, Florida, continuing its mission to educate and honor law enforcement professionals. A Permanent Home The museum finds its forever home in Titusville, Florida, welcoming visitors to explore its exhibits and learn its stories. Supporting Families USLEF leads in providing vital resources, financial aid, and emotional support to the families of fallen officers and those disabled in the line of duty. Shaping the Future With innovative training and education programs, USLEF prepares future officers and citizens to uphold safety and justice. 1960 1967 1989 1990 2003 Today Tomorrow Inside the Museum The American Police Hall of Fame Museum is a place to learn, explore and celebrate law enforcement for all the family! Through exciting exhibits, historic artifacts and fun, interactive activities, you will gain a unique insight into the challenges and triumphs of those who serve our communities. Buy Ticket Our Vision Educating the Public The museum aims to foster understanding and appreciation of law enforcement through engaging educational experiences like the Irish Connection digital exhibit. Inspiring Generations We hope to inspire the next generation of officers, leaders and citizens by showcasing the dedication, innovation and bravery of law enforcement professionals. Building Connections Our vision is to create a space where the public and law enforcement can connect; building mutual respect and understanding for a safer and stronger community. Who Are the United States Law Enforcement Foundation? The United States Law Enforcement Foundation (USLEF) is dedicated to supporting law enforcement officers, their families and the wider community. In addition to overseeing the American Police Hall of Fame and Museum, USLEF offers multiple programs such as The Hope Initiative to support officers’ children, provide emotional and financial support for families of fallen officers or those disabled in the line of duty. The USLEF wider programs promote public safety, and inspire the next generation of law enforcement. Together, we’re building a brighter future for the men and women who serve and protect our country. To learn more about the impact USLEF are having go to uslef.org. To learn more about the Police Family Survivors Fund go to afp-cc.org . Donate Friends of Law Enforcement Museum activities are sponsored, in part, by the Brevard County Board of County Commissioners, the Florida’s Space Coast Office of Tourism and The Brevard. Visit Us | American Police Hall of Fame Home About Us Memorial News & Events Shop Visit Us Award Program Donate Buy Ticket Plan Your Visit Located in Florida just off the NASA Causeway only minutes from the Kennedy Space Center and only 65 miles from Walt Disney World, enhance your vacation by visiting us. Opening Hours From 10 am to 4 pm, the last entry is at 3 pm. Open Tuesday through Saturday all year round except 24th to 26th December. Admission Adults: $15.00 Children Under 4 - FREE Children (Ages 4 - 12): $10.00 Military, AAA & Senior Citizens: $12.00 Law Enforcement Officers: $5.00 Family Survivors: $2.00 Click to enlarge How to find us Address: 6350 Horizon Drive, Titusville, FL 32780 Google Maps Waze In The Area Local Food Recommendation The Space Bar : 6245 Riverfront Ctr Blvd, Titusville, FL 32780, United States Beef ‘O’ Brady’s : 3745 Curtis Blvd, Port St John, FL 32927, United States Local Hotels Marriott Courtyard Titusville : 6245 Riverfront Ctr Blvd, Titusville, FL 32780, United States Hyatt Place Titusville : 6299 Riverfront Ctr Blvd, Titusville, FL 32780, United States Other Attractions Situated on Florida's Space Coast, we are just minutes away from Kennedy Space Center . We're so close that you may get to see a launch from our car park! Why not combine your trip with a visit to Disney World, Orlando only 65 miles away? Get Your Tickets Don’t miss your chance to explore the exciting history, innovation, and heroism of law enforcement. Secure your tickets today and get ready for a memorable experience! School/Group Pricing Bring your class for an educational and interactive field trip! We offer special pricing for school groups, making it easier for students to learn about the history and impacts of all aspects of law enforcement. Contact us for more information. Get In Touch Meeting and Event Space Have your next event in our spacious, multi-use room ideal for meetings, workshops, classes, private & community events, training sessions, celebrations, and more! Get In Touch FAQ Got questions? We've got answers! Here you'll find all the information you need to make the most of your experience. If you don't find what you're looking for, feel free to contact us at policeinfo@APHF.org . Q: Where is the American Police Hall of Fame? A: We’re located at 6350 Horizon Drive, Titusville, Florida, just minutes from Kennedy Space Center and convenient Orlando’s attractions. Q: What are the museum’s opening hours? The museum is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10:00 AM to 4:00 PM. Q: Is parking available? Yes, we offer free parking for all visitors. Along with disabled parking spots and space for buses. Q: Can I buy tickets at the door? We recommend buying your tickets online in advance to avoid disappointment, however if you are in the area visiting other attractions, you can purchase tickets on the door. Q: Are there discounts available? Yes! We offer discounted rates for veterans and active law enforcement officers. Q: Where does the money from ticket purchases go? The United States Law Enforcement Foundation is a nonprofit organization actively supporting law enforcement officers, their families and the wider community. The cost of tickets goes towards upkeep of the museum and memorial as well put into programs such as The Hope Initiative to fund scholarships, grants and anniversary gifts to families of fallen officers and those disabled in the line of duty. For the full list of programs visit uslef.org Q: Is the museum accessible for visitors with disabilities? Yes, the museum is fully wheelchair accessible, with designated parking and ramps for ease of access. Q: Are group tours available? Yes! We offer special rates and guided tours for school groups and other organizations. Q: How long should I plan for my visit? You can walk around the exhibits at your own pace. Most visitors spend about 2-3 hours exploring the exhibits and activities, but feel free to stay longer and enjoy everything we have to offer! Q: What is/isn’t included in admission? Your ticket gives you full access to the American Police Hall of Fame and Museum. For admission into the Shooting Center, you will need to book a separate ticket. Q: Are weapons permitted inside the museum? No weapons of any kind are permitted inside the American Police Hall of Fame and Museum including those belonging to off-duty law enforcement. Please leave items secured within your vehicle. Didn't answer your question? It is the nation's first national police museum and memorial dedicated to law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty. MUSEUM The Museum at The American Police Hall of Fame hosts nearly 11,000 exhibits and artifacts relating to law enforcement. Many of these exhibits are interactive and include a large collection of antique law enforcement vehicles, decommissioned fire arms and tools used by law enforcement officers. Stop by our kids corner where kids can dress the part of their favorite law enforcement officer, practice their detective skills in an interactive lab and make their own badge to take home. The United States Law Enforcement Eternal Flame October 20, 2020 Ground Broken for Eternal Flame, Walk of Heroes TITUSVILLE – On the heels of financial commitments from the Brevard County Commissioners and two national law enforcement organizations, as well as support from numerous businesses, individuals and television's John Walsh, the American Police Hall of Fame put shovels to dirt Oct. 16 in preparation for "phase one." "We began developing plans for this monument five years ago," Executive Director Barry Shepherd told the assembled celebrants. "And we are so proud and thrilled to finally be breaking ground on it. It's even more significant that we are doing so the day after celebrating our 60th anniversary. We are starting the next 60 years with great momentum and purpose." The Flame will pay tribute to law enforcement officers lost in the line of duty as well as to those who patrol the streets of America daily. The Walk of Heroes offers an opportunity for individuals, clubs, businesses etc. to purchase either a 4x8 or an 8x8 brick. "There is still time to purchase a brick for the first installation. This can be done on a secure site that you can access by going to www.USWalkofHeroes.org or you can download a form and mail in your order," explained Tara Dixon Engel, President of the Hall of Fame. "We have already begun clearing ground and, with the groundbreaking finished, we will be grading the land and prepping for paver installation. It is an exciting time around here. After the craziness and delays of 2020, we are ready to hit the ground running in 2021." During the Friday ceremony, letters of support for the project were read from "America's Most Wanted" star John Walsh, Senator Rick Scott (who prepared a video presentation), Governor Ron DeSantis, Congressman Bill Posey (who attended and read his letter), the NRA, the Police Benevolent Association, the NYPD's 10-13 Club, the 9463 Foundation and others. Visitors were treated to a replica of the planned Flame, complete with hundreds of twinkling lights on the stem of the structure, just below the flame itself. Guests of honor also included Commissioner Rita Pritchett, former Commissioner Robin Fisher, officials from Rush construction, board members and staff from The American Police Hall of Fame & Museum, and many others. "In response to the phone calls we are getting, yes, there is still opportunity for sponsorships or donations, both financial and in-kind, for the project," Shepherd noted. "The pinnacle donor spot is still available and we have a short list of companies in mind for that leadership gift, but we will meet with others who express interest in that level of visibility and involvement. Those seeking additional donor opportunities can contact Tara Dixon Engel at the Hall of Fame, while sponsorships are being handled by our Director of Sales, Events & Protocol, Janey Hicks." Project details, deadlines and related information will be available at www.LEFlame.org for the Flame and www.USWalkofHeroes.org for the paver path. To find out more, call 321-264-0911. Pictured, from left are: Brian Blanchard of the Tourism Development Council, Brian Donnelly of the 9463 Foundation, Chief John Lau of Titusville Police Department, Al Boettjer of the Police Benevolent Association, Sheriff Wayne Ivey of the Brevard County Sheriff's Office, Congressman Bill Posey, Barry Shepherd of American Police Hall of Fame, Brevard County Commissioner Rita Pritchett, William Chivers of Rush Construction, and Titusville Mayor Walt Johnson. Congressman Bill Posey expresses his support for the project. Titusville Mayor Walt Johnson presents Executive Director Barry Shepherd with a commemorative plaque. One of the nation's top indoor gun ranges is located in Titusville at 6350 Horizon Drive inside the American Police Hall of Fame & Museum which is a quarter of a mile east of US1 on SR405. This is a premier range that features 2 bays with 12 lanes in each. The range uses a combination of electronics and computerization, and it is fully air conditioned and it has HEPA air filtration. All firearms using pistol caliber ammunition are welcome, and modern sporting rifles using frangible ammunition may also be shot here. We have an extensive array of firearms available for rent, and we sell ammunition and targets. You may bring your own ammo and targets. We also have eye and ear protection available for rent. The range is open to the public, and the hours of operation are Noon to 8:00 PM Tuesday thru Friday, and Noon to 6:00PM Saturday and Sunday. Personal assistance is available at no cost. We have handgun leagues for adults in bullseye and tactical/practical disciplines and for kids (ages 8-17) using 22 rifles. Unless shooting in the kid's league or by special arrangement with scout troops, the minimum age for young people to shoot at the range is 13, and they must be accompanied by a parent. CLICK HERE to visit the main website of the AMERICAN POLICE Hall of Fame & Museum Annual Flag Display Honors Law Enforcement Families Hall of Fame Continues Flag Tradition Despite 2020 Ceremony Cancellation TITUSVILLE, FL – In honor of the May 15 Peace Officer Memorial Day, The American Police Hall of Fame & Museum once again has its flag display along 405, just south of Titusville. The flags represent fallen officer family members who are served by the compassionate programs headquartered at the Hall of Fame facility. Each year, the flags, which typically number around 13,000, are placed on the grounds of the Hall of Fame in cooperation with the Brevard County Sheriff's Department via inmates from the Brevard County jail. Although COVID-19 threw a monkey wrench into plans for this year's memorial observance, this is nonetheless a time of reflection and tribute at the Hall of Fame. "Although we are not holding our formal memorial service this year, we WILL have a special video tribute playing all day inside the museum's large training room," said CEO Barry Shepherd. "We want to make sure that local law enforcement and those civilians who support law enforcement have a place to come where they can reflect on the meaning of the day. The public is invited to visit the museum to watch the tribute anytime between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. It will be looping continuously. Admission to the museum is free all day. We encourage folks to come out and pay tribute to our men and women of the thin blue line and to those who gave all...in 2019 and in years past." For those who cannot make it to the facility, a link to the video tribute will be posted on the Hall of Fame website at www.APHF.org. Additionally, the facility is offering a virtual "Walk of Heroes" on its Facebook page, allowing the general public to pay tribute to law enforcement in general, current sworn officers, fallen or disabled officers or the families who support them. You can find the virtual tribute at https://www.facebook.com/APHF911/ For more information about the facility, go to www.APHF.org or email Policeinfo@aphf.org . Originated - 6/4/03

Welcome to The American Police Hall of Fame The American Police Hall of Fame & Museum is the moving force behind The United States Law Enforcement Eternal Flame and The Walk of Heroes . The Museum is located in Titusville Florida (just down the street from Kennedy Space Center), where our 50,000 sq ft facility has stood since 2003.  The Hall of Fame was founded in 1960 in Northport, Florida. Our facility offers compelling exhibits and interactives, STEM lessons for grades K-12, personal defense training for citizens, defensive tactics and related training for Law Enforcement Officers, as well as compassionate programming in support of the families of fallen officers and the families of disabled officers. Find out more about the facility at www.APHF.org or about the Eternal Flame at www.LEFlame.org . ​ We are at: 6350 Horizon Drive, Titusville, FL 32780 -- 321-264-0911 -- email Policeinfo@aphf.org or Tarae@aphf.org with questions. About Us | American Police Hall of Fame Home About Us Memorial News & Events Shop Visit Us Award Program Donate Buy Ticket Discover America's First Law Enforcement Museum Buy Ticket Our Story A Legacy Begins Founded by retired Police Chief Gerald Arenberg, the American Police Hall of Fame becomes the nation's first law enforcement museum. Reaching the Community A foundation is established to support law enforcement and the community. Expanding Support Two programs are founded to aid families of fallen officers and provide assistance to those injured in the line of duty. Moving Forward The museum relocates to Miami, Florida, continuing its mission to educate and honor law enforcement professionals. A Permanent Home The museum finds its forever home in Titusville, Florida, welcoming visitors to explore its exhibits and learn its stories. Supporting Families USLEF leads in providing vital resources, financial aid, and emotional support to the families of fallen officers and those disabled in the line of duty. Shaping the Future With innovative training and education programs, USLEF prepares future officers and citizens to uphold safety and justice. 1960 1967 1989 1990 2003 Today Tomorrow Inside the Museum The American Police Hall of Fame Museum is a place to learn, explore and celebrate law enforcement for all the family! Through exciting exhibits, historic artifacts and fun, interactive activities, you will gain a unique insight into the challenges and triumphs of those who serve our communities. Buy Ticket Our Vision Educating the Public The museum aims to foster understanding and appreciation of law enforcement through engaging educational experiences like the Irish Connection digital exhibit. Inspiring Generations We hope to inspire the next generation of officers, leaders and citizens by showcasing the dedication, innovation and bravery of law enforcement professionals. Building Connections Our vision is to create a space where the public and law enforcement can connect; building mutual respect and understanding for a safer and stronger community. Who Are the United States Law Enforcement Foundation? The United States Law Enforcement Foundation (USLEF) is dedicated to supporting law enforcement officers, their families and the wider community. In addition to overseeing the American Police Hall of Fame and Museum, USLEF offers multiple programs such as The Hope Initiative to support officers’ children, provide emotional and financial support for families of fallen officers or those disabled in the line of duty. The USLEF wider programs promote public safety, and inspire the next generation of law enforcement. Together, we’re building a brighter future for the men and women who serve and protect our country. To learn more about the impact USLEF are having go to uslef.org. To learn more about the Police Family Survivors Fund go to afp-cc.org . Log In Log In GRADUATE VOLUNTEER PROGRAM This program is open to individuals enrolled in graduate-level health professional and/or public health degree programs. ​ ​ During each volunteer cycle, APHF receives a number of exceptional applicants. The volunteer cohort for American Pacific Health Foundation has become increasingly diverse while maintaining the professionalism, integrity, and scale required to personally serve our local community. Becoming a Volunteer Thank you for your interest in joining our APHF team! When serving as a graduate volunteer with American Pacific Health Foundation, you will have the opportunity to interpret test results, perform data analysis, and provide education and health consultations to outreach participants under the supervision of an APHF preceptor. In addition, you will participate in APHF's linkage-to-care committee, in which you will be thoroughly trained to follow-up with patients who received positive hepatitis test results or fulfill criteria for metabolic syndrome and guide patients through health systems to establish more longterm care for routine checkups and treatment. Furthermore, graduate volunteers can assist in the development of research projects and fundraising initiatives for APHF community health screenings . Program Expectations & Events APHF Expectations Volunteer Expectations Types of Outreaches Opportunity to serve minorities and at risk populations through educational and clinical outreaches within the community in San Diego County Development of patient care, leadership, communication, and project management skills Mentorship and a network of healthcare professionals Thorough training on APHF's mission, venue setup, data collection and processing, healthcare equipment operation, and direct patient care recommendations Transportation assistance to educational and clinical outreaches Experiential learning in community health settings. UCSD pharmacy students can earn IPPE service-learning credits at APHF outreaches. Professional conduct during outreaches and respectful engagement with community members, volunteer staff, and volunteer health professionals Completion of Volunteer Onboarding, which includes both virtual and in-person training components, and payment of annual $25 membership fee Proof of completion of COVID-19 vaccination series with recommended boosters Fulfillment of a 1-year member term and participation in at least 3 APHF events. If you have been approved to serve as a Graduate Volunteer once, you will not need to reapply unless you are determined inactive by the Executive Board. 			   national police museum and memorial dedicated to American law enforcement officers

The Museum, through interactive displays, simulators and nearly 11,000 artifacts, educates the public about the history and current trends of American law enforcement. It is the nation's first national police museum and memorial dedicated to law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty. MUSEUM The Museum at The American Police Hall of Fame hosts nearly 11,000 exhibits and artifacts relating to law enforcement. Many of these exhibits are interactive and include a large collection of antique law enforcement vehicles, decommissioned fire arms and tools used by law enforcement officers. Stop by our kids corner where kids can dress the part of their favorite law enforcement officer, practice their detective skills in an interactive lab and make their own badge to take home. The United States Law Enforcement Eternal Flame October 20, 2020 Ground Broken for Eternal Flame, Walk of Heroes TITUSVILLE – On the heels of financial commitments from the Brevard County Commissioners and two national law enforcement organizations, as well as support from numerous businesses, individuals and television's John Walsh, the American Police Hall of Fame put shovels to dirt Oct. 16 in preparation for "phase one." "We began developing plans for this monument five years ago," Executive Director Barry Shepherd told the assembled celebrants. "And we are so proud and thrilled to finally be breaking ground on it. It's even more significant that we are doing so the day after celebrating our 60th anniversary. We are starting the next 60 years with great momentum and purpose." The Flame will pay tribute to law enforcement officers lost in the line of duty as well as to those who patrol the streets of America daily. The Walk of Heroes offers an opportunity for individuals, clubs, businesses etc. to purchase either a 4x8 or an 8x8 brick. "There is still time to purchase a brick for the first installation. This can be done on a secure site that you can access by going to www.USWalkofHeroes.org or you can download a form and mail in your order," explained Tara Dixon Engel, President of the Hall of Fame. "We have already begun clearing ground and, with the groundbreaking finished, we will be grading the land and prepping for paver installation. It is an exciting time around here. After the craziness and delays of 2020, we are ready to hit the ground running in 2021." During the Friday ceremony, letters of support for the project were read from "America's Most Wanted" star John Walsh, Senator Rick Scott (who prepared a video presentation), Governor Ron DeSantis, Congressman Bill Posey (who attended and read his letter), the NRA, the Police Benevolent Association, the NYPD's 10-13 Club, the 9463 Foundation and others. Visitors were treated to a replica of the planned Flame, complete with hundreds of twinkling lights on the stem of the structure, just below the flame itself. Guests of honor also included Commissioner Rita Pritchett, former Commissioner Robin Fisher, officials from Rush construction, board members and staff from The American Police Hall of Fame & Museum, and many others. "In response to the phone calls we are getting, yes, there is still opportunity for sponsorships or donations, both financial and in-kind, for the project," Shepherd noted. "The pinnacle donor spot is still available and we have a short list of companies in mind for that leadership gift, but we will meet with others who express interest in that level of visibility and involvement. Those seeking additional donor opportunities can contact Tara Dixon Engel at the Hall of Fame, while sponsorships are being handled by our Director of Sales, Events & Protocol, Janey Hicks." Project details, deadlines and related information will be available at www.LEFlame.org for the Flame and www.USWalkofHeroes.org for the paver path. To find out more, call 321-264-0911. Pictured, from left are: Brian Blanchard of the Tourism Development Council, Brian Donnelly of the 9463 Foundation, Chief John Lau of Titusville Police Department, Al Boettjer of the Police Benevolent Association, Sheriff Wayne Ivey of the Brevard County Sheriff's Office, Congressman Bill Posey, Barry Shepherd of American Police Hall of Fame, Brevard County Commissioner Rita Pritchett, William Chivers of Rush Construction, and Titusville Mayor Walt Johnson. Congressman Bill Posey expresses his support for the project. Titusville Mayor Walt Johnson presents Executive Director Barry Shepherd with a commemorative plaque. We encourage you to work for PEACE in your streets, DIALOG in your communities, and UNDERSTANDING of the challenges faced by our first responders, even as we expect them to understand their citizenry. One of the nation's top indoor gun ranges is located in Titusville at 6350 Horizon Drive inside the American Police Hall of Fame & Museum which is a quarter of a mile east of US1 on SR405. This is a premier range that features 2 bays with 12 lanes in each. The range uses a combination of electronics and computerization, and it is fully air conditioned and it has HEPA air filtration. All firearms using pistol caliber ammunition are welcome, and modern sporting rifles using frangible ammunition may also be shot here. We have an extensive array of firearms available for rent, and we sell ammunition and targets. You may bring your own ammo and targets. We also have eye and ear protection available for rent. The range is open to the public, and the hours of operation are Noon to 8:00 PM Tuesday thru Friday, and Noon to 6:00PM Saturday and Sunday. Personal assistance is available at no cost. We have handgun leagues for adults in bullseye and tactical/practical disciplines and for kids (ages 8-17) using 22 rifles. Unless shooting in the kid's league or by special arrangement with scout troops, the minimum age for young people to shoot at the range is 13, and they must be accompanied by a parent. CLICK HERE to visit the main website of the AMERICAN POLICE Hall of Fame & Museum Annual Flag Display Honors Law Enforcement Families Hall of Fame Continues Flag Tradition Despite 2020 Ceremony Cancellation TITUSVILLE, FL – In honor of the May 15 Peace Officer Memorial Day, The American Police Hall of Fame & Museum once again has its flag display along 405, just south of Titusville. The flags represent fallen officer family members who are served by the compassionate programs headquartered at the Hall of Fame facility. Each year, the flags, which typically number around 13,000, are placed on the grounds of the Hall of Fame in cooperation with the Brevard County Sheriff's Department via inmates from the Brevard County jail. Although COVID-19 threw a monkey wrench into plans for this year's memorial observance, this is nonetheless a time of reflection and tribute at the Hall of Fame. "Although we are not holding our formal memorial service this year, we WILL have a special video tribute playing all day inside the museum's large training room," said CEO Barry Shepherd. "We want to make sure that local law enforcement and those civilians who support law enforcement have a place to come where they can reflect on the meaning of the day. The public is invited to visit the museum to watch the tribute anytime between 10 a.m. and 6 p.m. It will be looping continuously. Admission to the museum is free all day. We encourage folks to come out and pay tribute to our men and women of the thin blue line and to those who gave all...in 2019 and in years past." For those who cannot make it to the facility, a link to the video tribute will be posted on the Hall of Fame website at www.APHF.org. Additionally, the facility is offering a virtual "Walk of Heroes" on its Facebook page, allowing the general public to pay tribute to law enforcement in general, current sworn officers, fallen or disabled officers or the families who support them. You can find the virtual tribute at https://www.facebook.com/APHF911/ For more information about the facility, go to www.APHF.org or email Policeinfo@aphf.org . Originated - 6/4/03

Privacy Policy | American Police Hall of Fame Home About Us Memorial News & Events Shop Visit Us Award Program Donate Buy Ticket Privacy Policy This Website is owned and operated by the United States Law Enforcement Foundation. We understand that visitors to our site may be concerned about the information they provide to us, and what we do with that information. This Privacy Policy addresses those concerns. This policy may be updated from time to time. If you have any questions or comments about our Privacy Policy, you can contact us at: United States Law Enforcement Foundation 6350 Horizon Dr. Titusville, Florida 32780 Telephone: (321) 264-0911 Fax: (321) 264-0033 e-mail: policeinfo@aphf.org USLEF Policy USLEF uses its best efforts to respect the privacy of its online visitors. At our site, we do not collect personally identifiable information from individuals unless they provide it to us voluntarily and knowingly. This means we do not require you to register or provide information to us in order to view our site. USLEF respects the privacy of its members, visitors and donors, both digital and “real world.” We do not collect personally identifiable information from individuals unless they provide it to us voluntarily and knowingly. This means we do not require you to register or provide information to us in order to view our website. USLEF only gathers personally identifiable data, such as names, addresses, zip/postal codes, e-mail addresses, etc., when voluntarily submitted by a visitor. For example, personally identifiable information may be collected in order to respond to a stated desire to volunteer time to USLEF or to make a donation online. This information is used by our organization(s) for internal purposes. With your knowledge and permission, these names are occasionally shared with other organizations that share our goals. This process is carefully controlled and we do so with the belief that you will find that these groups compatible with your values and interests. We follow this policy in all interactions, both on- and off-line. And, in the event that you do not want your information shared with other entities, we offer an “opt out” box in each area of the site where you provide personal information. If you are not on-line and still wish to opt out, you may call us at 321-264-0911 or email us at policeinfo@aphf.org and we will see to it that your name is removed from our list sharing activities. As a consumer-friendly organization, USLEF will continue to work to maintain the privacy of its members, donors and visitors. Credit Card Security Issues We care about the safety and security of your transaction. We use high-grade encryption and the https security protocol to communicate with your browser software. This method is the industry standard security protocol, which makes it extremely difficult for anyone else to intercept the credit card information you send to us. Contributions to the organization may also be made by calling 1-321-264-0911 or by writing us directly. About Us | United States Law Enforcement Foundation DONATE Home About Us Programs The Hope Initiative The Irish Connection The Force Defenders Guardian Academy The Hero Collection Beyond the Badge Officer Education Visit Us Memorial Ways to Give Donate DONATE Our Vision & Mission The United States Law Enforcement Foundation (USLEF) stands at the forefront of innovation and progress in the law enforcement community. For more than five decades, we have served as unwavering advocates and supporters of law enforcement professionals, leveraging cutting-edge technology, including artificial intelligence (AI), to revolutionize how we serve, inspire, and educate those in the field. About Us Watch our story unfold—learn about our impact, the people we serve, and our commitment to law enforcement through the video below Meet our leadership team Our Legacy Since 1960 the profession of Law Enforcement has been supported through three related organizations: American Police Hall of Fame and Museum (APHF) The American Police Hall of Fame & Museum is a tribute to those who lost their lives in the line of duty and a celebration of U.S. law enforcement history. Founded in 1960 by former officer Gerald Arenberg after he was injured by a drunk driver. Learn More About the APHF National Association of Chiefs of Police (NACOP) The National Association of Chiefs of Police (NACOP) advocates for law enforcement and security personnel at all levels, promoting their interests and building public trust. Guided by an advisory board and annual member surveys. Learn More About the NACOP American Federation of Police and Concerned Citizens (AFPCC) Founded in 1978, the American Federation of Police and Concerned Citizens (AFPCC) supports officers and their families through a range of services. AFPCC provides survivor programs for families of officers killed in the line of duty. Learn More About the AFPCC Be a Part of Our Mission Join us in supporting law enforcement officers and their families. Your contribution helps us provide education, emotional wellness resources, and financial literacy programs. Support USLEF Financial Disclosures In October 2023, AFPCC merged with the National Association of Chiefs of Police (NACOP) to become the United States Law Enforcement Foundation (USLEF).
